attributes.comment:
I have been doing immigration law since the 1980s. Since then, the fees have
increased dramatically, and so have processing times.

The fees are already very high. They put a burden on a person who is just asking for
an adjudication under law. The fees are high enough to be a financial burden on the
middle class. These raises in the fee bring the mere request for adjudication into a
place where only the upper middle class has a chance to just ask for an adjudication.

In addition there are many deadlines, and poorer people may not be able to come up
with the money in time, making it a matter of wealth as to whether or not one can
simply ask for an adjudication.

This burden falls on U.S. citizens. They are the ones filing for their alien family
member or employee. A U.S. citizen has a right to marry the person of their choice, if
they choose to marry an alien, the filing fees make a sort of penalty. Filing fees should
be just minor fees, not so high that they are a major factor in a person's budget.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Laraine A. Ryan
